steps.text: What is Psychology?
steps.hint: Psychology comes from Greek words 'psyche' (soul) and 'logos' (study)

steps.text: Scientific study of human mind and behavior
steps.hint: Psychology uses scientific methods to understand thoughts, feelings, and actions

steps.text: Explores cognitive processes and mental states
steps.hint: Cognitive processes include memory, attention, perception, and problem-solving

steps.text: Analyzes individual and group dynamics
steps.hint: Social psychology examines how people influence each other

steps.text: Major Fields
Clinical Psychology: Diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders
steps.hint: Clinical psychologists often work in hospitals, clinics, or private practice

steps.text: Cognitive Psychology: Study of mental processes like memory and learning
steps.hint: Cognitive psychologists investigate how we think, remember, and solve problems

steps.text: Developmental Psychology: Changes across the lifespan
steps.hint: From infancy to old age, developmental psychology tracks human growth

steps.text: Social Psychology: How people interact and influence each other
steps.hint: Topics include conformity, persuasion, prejudice, and group behavior

options.label: Behavioral
options.description: Focuses on observable behaviors and how they're learned through conditioning

options.label: Cognitive
options.description: Emphasizes mental processes like thinking, memory, and problem-solving

options.label: Humanistic
options.description: Centers on personal growth, self-actualization, and human potential

steps.text: Step 1: Observe and ask questions about behavior
steps.hint: Good research starts with curiosity about why people act the way they do

steps.text: Step 2: Form a testable hypothesis
steps.hint: A hypothesis is a specific, falsifiable prediction about relationships between variables

steps.text: Step 3: Design and conduct experiments
steps.hint: Experiments use controlled conditions to test cause-and-effect relationships

steps.text: Step 4: Analyze data using statistics
steps.hint: Statistical analysis helps determine if results are meaningful or due to chance

steps.text: Step 5: Draw conclusions and share findings
steps.hint: Peer review and replication are crucial for scientific validity

steps.text: The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons, each capable of connecting with thousands of others.
steps.hint: This creates an incredibly complex network for processing information

steps.text: Key Brain Structures
Frontal Lobe: Executive functions, decision-making, personality
steps.hint: Damage to the frontal lobe can dramatically change personality and behavior

steps.text: Temporal Lobe: Memory, language comprehension, auditory processing
steps.hint: The hippocampus in the temporal lobe is crucial for forming new memories

steps.text: Occipital Lobe: Visual processing and interpretation
steps.hint: All visual information from your eyes is processed in the occipital lobe

steps.text: Parietal Lobe: Sensory integration, spatial awareness
steps.hint: Helps you understand where your body is in space and process touch sensations

steps.text: Types of Memory
Sensory Memory: Brief storage of sensory information (< 1 second)
steps.hint: Like a camera flash - information is captured but fades almost immediately

steps.text: Short-term Memory: Temporary storage, limited capacity (7¬±2 items)
steps.hint: This is why phone numbers are typically 7 digits - it fits our short-term capacity

steps.text: Long-term Memory: Potentially unlimited storage duration
steps.hint: Can be divided into explicit (conscious) and implicit (unconscious) memories

steps.text: Effective Learning Strategies
Spaced repetition: Review material at increasing intervals
steps.hint: More effective than cramming - helps move information to long-term memory

steps.text: Active recall: Test yourself rather than passively re-reading
steps.hint: The act of retrieving information strengthens memory pathways

steps.text: Elaborative encoding: Connect new info to existing knowledge
steps.hint: Creating meaningful connections makes information easier to remember

steps.text: Remember These Key Points
Psychology is a science that uses empirical methods
steps.hint: Not just opinions - psychology relies on data and controlled experiments

steps.text: Multiple perspectives offer different insights into behavior
steps.hint: Behavioral, cognitive, humanistic, and biological perspectives complement each other

steps.text: Understanding the brain helps us understand the mind
steps.hint: Neuroscience and psychology are increasingly interconnected fields

steps.text: Effective learning requires active engagement and strategy
steps.hint: Apply spaced repetition, active recall, and elaborative encoding to your studies

steps.text: Continue exploring psychology to better understand yourself and others!
steps.hint: Psychology is relevant to every aspect of human life
